Epoxide ring-opening is a key reaction in organic chemistry. We have previously shown that B(C6F5)3, a strongly Lewis acidic arylborane, exhibited high rates and unusual selectivities for catalyzing the ring-opening of aliphatic epoxides with alcohols. Here we compare catalysts of the form B(C6H5−XFX)3 (x = 5, 4, 3, and 0) and determine that moderately Lewis acidic arylboranes have higher regioselectivity, but slower rates in this reaction. At high temperatures, these arylboranes can also hydrolyze into inactive species. However, deactivation is suppressed in the presence of co-catalytic amounts of 1,2-propanediol, and DFT calculations suggest a role for arylborane-H2O-diol complexes. Thermal stabilization and regioselectivity enhancement by diol are both more pronounced for B(C6F5)3 than for less Lewis acidic B(C6HF4)3 and B(C6H2F3)3 catalysts. These results further demonstrate the catalytic relevance of H-bound networks of arylboranes and diols and enable their use at higher temperatures and greatly increased rates. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Epoxide ring-opening Catalyst Arylborane Thermal stabilization Hydrogen bonding 1 Introduction Tris(pentafluorophenyl)borane (also known as BCF, and here referred to as F 5 AB) and related fluorinated arylboranes (FABs) form a special class of Lewis acid catalysts that participate in a range of reactions [1–3]. F 5 AB, is highly Lewis-acidic, water-tolerant at moderate conditions, and has been employed in a range of reactions including aldol-type [4], hydrosilylation [5,6], hydrogenation [7,8], oxidation [9], cationic polymerization [10], ring-opening polymerization [11,12], amination [13] and frustrated Lewis pair chemistry [14]. Commercially, epoxide ring-opening is employed in the synthesis of polyether polyols, which are key intermediates for manufacturing polyurethane polymers [15]. As described in Scheme 1, ring-opening of a terminal epoxide such as 1,2-epoxyoctane or propylene oxide by an alcohol nucleophile yields primary (P1) and secondary (P2) polyols.[16] As the latter are sluggish reactants for certain polyurethane applications [17], it is desired to have catalysts that selectively yield P1 polyols. Chromatographic separation of the P1 and P2 isomers can be challenging (see Supporting Information), which further motivates a search for more selective catalysts. We have previously observed that, while conventional catalysts were unselective to P1 polyols, FABs can give high rates and regioselectivities for ring-opening of the terminal epoxide 1,2-epoxyoctane by alcohols [18,19]. In addition, we also described a route to further enhance reaction regioselectivity towards P1 by exploiting favorable H-bonding interactions with the product or with co-catalytic amounts of added diols or other hydrogen-bond acceptors (HBAs) [20]. Here, we compare the rates and selectivities of 1-propanol alcoholysis of 1,2-epoxyoctane with F 5 AB and two other arylborane catalysts: B(C6H2F3)3 or F 3 AB, which has previously been employed in epoxide ring-opening [11], hydrogenation [21,22], hydrosilylation [23], deoxygenation [24], and B(C6HF4)3 or F 4 AB, which has been reported to have applications in hydrogen activation [25,26]. We first address the activity of these catalysts at higher temperatures to address the tradeoff of rate and catalyst stability. Then, we demonstrate an important effect of hydrogen bond acceptors (HBAs) on the stability and selectivity of some of the arylborane catalysts. 2 Experimental details F 5 AB was obtained from commercial suppliers while F 3 AB and F 4 AB were synthesized following literature protocols (see SI for full experimental details) [27,28]. Catalytic studies were performed in 20 mL glass vials with PTFE septa on a Glass Col heated shaker plate at 500 RPM shaking speed. The desired arylborane (1 eq./0.1 mol%) was dissolved in 1 mL o-xylene (containing ~150 ppm H2O or approximately equimolar with respect to arylborane), and 10–20 eq./1–2 mol% propanediol was added in some cases. The vial was then capped, heated to reaction temperature, and incubated for 5–60 min. Unless explicitly stated, catalysts were incubated for 15 min before reaction. The reaction was initiated by the addition of pre-heated 1 mL 1,2-epoxyoctane (1000 eq.) and 2 mL 1-propanol (4000 eq.) using a syringe. We have previously noted a strong dependence of rates, selectivities, and catalytic mechanisms on the amount of water present [19]. Here, initial water levels were maintained at 600–800 ppm by mixing appropriate amounts of anhydrous and water-rich 1-propanol, as determined by a Mettler Toledo Karl Fisher C30 titrator. After the reaction was initiated, 50 µL reaction mixture aliquots were periodically withdrawn, diluted in 1.5 mL methyl t-butyl ether and analyzed by GC-FID on a Restek low-bleed ‘Stabilwax’ polyethylene glycol column [60 m x 0.25 mm × 0.5 µm df]. GC response factors were acquired using calibration curves for authentic reactants and products against o-xylene (internal standard). Neither 1,2-octanediol, the hydrolysis product, nor octanal, the epoxide rearrangement product, were detected in the reaction mixture, with a lower detection limit of 2% conversion. Regioselectivities are integrated values reported as molar ratios of [P1]:[P2] present in the system at the corresponding time point and plotted against conversion to be able to compare catalysts of varying rates. Percent conversion is defined as 100x(1-[Epoxide]/[Epoxide]0). Mass balance, defined as ([P1]+[P2])/([Epoxide]0-[Epoxide]) is > 95% at conversion < 50%, and decreases at higher conversion due to the formation of oligomers that are undetectable by GC due to their high molecular weight. Apparent turnover frequencies (TOF) are reported as initial values and calculated by dividing apparent rates, using a linear fit of epoxide concentration against time at < 20 min, by catalyst concentration. All rates and selectivities reported in the manuscript are derived from GC analysis. However, P1 and P2 have been isolated in multi-gram batches by the procedures in this manuscript; see supporting information for full experimental details. VT 19F NMR spectra during F 5 AB decomposition were acquired as follows. F 5 AB (~10 mM) and α,α,α-trifluorotoluene (reference and internal standard, 15 mM) were added to o-xylene in an Ar-purged glove box. The water level was 450–500 ppm, or 2–3 eq. with respect to F 5 AB. 20 eq. propylene glycol were added to some experiments. 0.65 mL of the resulting solution was transferred to a J-Young NMR tube. NMR spectra were acquired on a 400 MHz Bruker Avance III HD Nanobay system equipped with SampleXpress autosampler and a BBFO Smart probe with Z-Gradient. Prior to reaction initiation, the instrument was thermally equilibrated at the desired reaction temperature for 30 min. The NMR set point temperature was calibrated using 1H NMR peak separation for neat ethylene glycol between 75 and 130 °C. 4 scans yielded S/N > 300 at 110 °C. T1 relaxation delays were determined to be 1.5–1.8 s, and the resulting D1 delay was set to 15 s, greater than the recommended value of 3–5x T1. Spectra were collected approximately every five minutes, referenced to trifluorotoluene (−63 ppm), exponentially apodised with 2–5 Hz, auto-phased, baseline-corrected, and relevant species were integrated. As in our previous studies [18–20], the Gaussian 16 suite of programs [29], was used to perform all density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Following benchmarking studies, [18] geometries, single point energies, and frequencies of each arylborane adduct were calculated at the B3LYP-D3BJ/6–31 +G(d,p) [30–32], theory level. Solvation effects were captured using the SMD solvation model with 1-propanol chosen as the implicit solvent. Lowest-energy geometries were confirmed using dihedral scans and conformational searches. Basis set superposition error (BSSE) for the formation of F X AB-H2O complexes was calculated to be + 2.6 ± 0.1 kcal/mol. The error was insensitive to arylborane structure and was thus not relevant for comparisons among them. Energies reported here are not corrected for BSSE because we previously showed that calculations underestimated experimental energies of adduct formation at all levels of theory [17]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of catalyst identity on rates and selectivities Chart 1 lists the series of arylboranes used in this work. The Lewis acidity of the arylboranes increases as F 3 AB < F 4 AB < F 5 AB, as determined by the Guttmann Beckett method. Experimental values of the Guttman Beckett acceptor number collected by the authors agree with those reported in the literature [25, 27, 33]. Fig. 1 shows epoxide conversion plotted against time and selectivity plotted against conversion for the three catalysts at 60 oC. Selectivity is plotted against conversion in order to compare catalysts of widely differing rates. F 3 AB, the weakest Lewis acid, was also the slowest (Fig. 1a) and attained < 10% conversion over 3 h under the test conditions. Arylboranes with lower Lewis acidities, such as triphenylborane, show no appreciable conversion under these conditions (Fig. S1). Given the already slow rates over F 3 AB, we did not study other fluorinated arylboranes of lower Lewis acidities. Among the three catalysts, rates increased as F 3 AB < F 4 AB < F 5 AB, in line with their increasing Lewis acidities. However, regioselectivities trended inversely (Fig. 1b) at any level of conversion, but the differences were particularly pronounced at low conversion. As we have seen previously [20], the selectivity of F 5 AB is low at low conversion, then increases with increasing conversion. F 4 AB showed broadly similar behavior, except that selectivities were higher at all conversions than for F 5 AB, eventually reaching a P1:P2 selectivity of 3.8. Finally, F 3 AB maintained a P1:P2 selectivity of ~4.0 at all conversions recorded. Unfortunately, the low reactivity of F 3 AB precluded the determination of selectivity at high conversion since the catalyst reached only 32% conversion after 13 h under these conditions. In our prior work on F 5 AB [19, 20], the increase in selectivity with conversion was attributed to a change in catalyst speciation. Computational modeling and experimental data provided evidence that catalytically relevant hydrogen-bound complexes form between arylborane, water, the alcohol nucleophile, the epoxide, and other hydrogen-bond acceptors (HBAs) including the reaction products P1 and P2. DFT and microkinetic modeling suggested that complexes with only water or alcohol were relatively unselective, while both the bare Lewis acid and complexes with the product could be intrinsically selective. In all, six distinct arylborane species were thermodynamically accessible and kinetically relevant under reaction conditions, in addition to more than a dozen spectator species. Correspondingly, experimental selectivity increased with increasing product concentrations, either from deliberate addition, altered reaction conditions, or increasing conversion. In the prior work, further control experiments and the addition of non-coordinating bases confirmed that Brønsted acid catalysis was unselective and not relevant under reaction conditions for these arylboranes. We have also confirmed here that P1 and P2 do not interconvert under reaction conditions (Table S1). Here, the increasing selectivity with conversion for both F 4 AB and F 5 AB (Fig. 1b) suggest that HBA-mediated selectivity enhancement is a general phenomenon for boranes with these Lewis acidities. In contrast, the stable selectivity of F 3 AB with respect to conversion suggests that this borane leads to only a single catalytically relevant species under reaction conditions. DFT simulations (below) show that this less Lewis acidic catalyst forms much weaker complexes with water. As a consequence, we expect that only the direct coordination of epoxide to F 3 AB would be catalytically relevant, and the selectivity would be much less dependent on reaction conditions or conversion. Additionally, we previously observed that the regioselectivity of F 5 AB could be enhanced using as little as 2–20 eq. (relative to catalyst) propylene glycol or similar diols as HBA [20]. Microkinetic modeling ascribed this to the favorable thermodynamics of forming F 5 AB-H2O-glycol complexes and the high intrinsic activity and selectivity of those complexes, as compared to some of the other hydrogen-bound complexes. The improved selectivity appeared to arise from the diol additive forming H-bonds with the incoming alcohol and directing it towards the more substituted carbon. Here, adding 10–20 eq. propylene glycol has no significant effect on the apparent rate constants for epoxide ring opening for any of the tested arylboranes (comparing Figs. 1a and 2a; Table S2), but leads to high regioselectivities for all three catalysts (Fig. 2b). The already-high selectivity of F 3 AB is not significantly changed, but there are substantial increases in selectivity for F 4 AB and F 5 AB, especially at lower conversion. In prior work on F 5 AB [19], we noted that reaction regioselectivity was enhanced on increasing temperature from 10° to 70°C. Moreover, F 3 AB is regioselective but sluggish for epoxide ring-opening at 60ºC, suggesting experiments at higher temperature to achieve appreciable conversions. Epoxide alcoholysis is employed industrially in the manufacture of polyols at temperatures up to 110 oC [34]. Therefore, we tested the catalysts at 90ºC and 110ºC. Fig. 3a shows that the increase in temperature substantially increased reaction rates, and all catalysts attained > 85% conversion in < 15 min at 110 oC, under these conditions. The regioselectivity remained practically unchanged at the higher temperatures for F 3 AB but were improved for F 4 AB and F 5 AB. Selectivity data are reported at high conversion for 110ºC due to the rapidity of the reaction at these conditions. The rates and selectivities were quite similar at 90ºC (Fig. S2) to the data at 110ºC. However, F 3 AB was unable to reach 100% conversion at 90 oC despite its high rate, which suggested catalyst decomposition is competitive with catalytic turnover at these temperatures. 3.2 Addressing catalyst decomposition at elevated temperature Overall, rates and selectivities were generally improved or held constant by running the reaction at higher temperatures for all catalysts, which is promising from a utility standpoint. However, the lack of a clear trend in rate or selectivity with respect to arylborane Lewis acidity, as was seen at 60ºC, suggests that multiple effects may dictate the overall catalytic behavior at higher temperatures. In particular, F 3 AB appears to have deactivated at 90ºC before 100% conversion, and others have reported that F 5 AB hydrolyzes to B(C6F5)2OH, B(C6F5)(OH)2, and eventually H3BO3, in presence of residual H2O at elevated temperatures [8, 35, 36]. Therefore, we sought to understand the impact of arylborane decomposition at these higher temperatures. First, we confirmed that F 5 AB hydrolyzes at our reaction conditions and temperatures of 90ºC and higher. A representative 19F NMR study at 120 oC ( Fig. 4) shows complete decomposition of F 5 AB in o-xylene and appearance of B(C6F5)2OH, B(C6F5)(OH)2, and C6F5H after 2 h of incubation. Separately, we determined that neither B(C6F5)2OH nor B(C6F5)(OH)2 were catalytically active at any of the conditions studied in this work (Fig. S3). Thus, catalyst hydrolysis is expected to decrease overall rates and may also impact reaction regioselectivity by altering the complex catalyst speciation that occurs under these conditions. Next, we hypothesized that diol additives might also have an impact on catalyst decomposition at elevated temperatures. In a series of experiments ( Fig. 5, Tables S2-S5), we studied the effect of incubation time and the presence of propylene glycol on catalyst activity and selectivity at 60ºC and 110ºC for each of the three arylboranes. Catalysts were dissolved in o-xylene containing 150 ppm residual water (~1 eq with respect to borane) with or without added propylene glycol and held at reaction temperature for 5, 30, or 60 min, before addition of the reactant mixture. Fig. 5a shows that the catalytic activity and selectivity of F 5 AB was not significantly changed by time of incubation at 60 oC. Therefore, catalyst hydrolysis at 60 oC does not appear to play a significant role over the time scales and conditions relevant to those studies. On the other hand, rates and selectivities were significantly eroded for all catalysts after extended incubation in o-xylene at 110ºC, in the absence of the propylene glycol additive (Fig. 5b-d). The apparent turnover frequencies (TOFs) after 60 min of incubation decreased by 65–90% for F 5 AB, F 4 AB, and F 3 AB at 110ºC. Without added glycol, F 5 AB and F 4 AB also had decreases in selectivity with increased incubation time, but the selectivity for F 3 AB was not significantly affected. When 2 mol% (20 eq. relative to arylborane) propylene glycol was added to the initial o-xylene solution, selectivities remained high in all cases, and for all incubation times. In the presence of propylene glycol, turnover rates were unaffected by 60 min incubation for F 5 AB, decreased only 30% for F 4 AB, but still decreased by over 90% for F 3 AB. Overall, the propylene glycol additive appears to remarkably stabilize F 5 AB against deactivation during incubation, while separately increasing its regioselectivity at all levels of conversion and having no negative effect on rates. The stabilization of F 5 AB was directly studied by 19F NMR ( Fig. 6). With 20 eq. added glycol, there was < 5% decomposition after 1 hr at 110 °C, consistent with the functional testing above. The detailed kinetics of F 5 AB-decomposition appear to be complex and will be further investigated in the future. As seen above, the effects of propylene glycol are less pronounced for the slightly less Lewis acidic F 4 AB, and largely absent for F 3 AB. A unifying hypothesis ( Scheme 2) for these observations is that F X AB-H2O-glycol complexes are relatively more favored for the more Lewis acidic arylboranes, and that they contribute both to improved regioselectivity under reaction conditions (prior section) and stability against hydrolysis to an inactive borinic acid during incubation (this section). Density functional theory calculations ( Fig. 7; Table S6) show that F 5 AB and F 4 AB form stable F X AB-H2O-glycol complexes, based on free energies of formation of − 6.3 and − 5.6 kcal/mol respectively (relative to isolated borane, H2O, and glycol). F 5 AB-H2O-glycol has the lowest free energy of formation of the ten F 5 AB-H2O-X or F 5 AB-glycol-X complexes calculated (X = none, propanol, epoxide, water, and glycol; Table S7). Because of their similar structure and reactivity patterns, energy trends are expected to be very similar for F 4 AB. Regardless of the exact energies of these complexes, it appears that ‘tying up’ F 4 AB or F 5 AB as water/glycol-containing complexes renders them less prone to hydrolysis during incubation in o-xylene. On the other hand, the free energy of forming F 3 AB-H2O complexes is positive by 2.4 kcal, and the overall free energy of forming a F 3 AB-H2O-glycol complex is still slightly positive. These values are consistent with the lower Lewis acidity of F 3 AB. Overall, the differences in formation free energies between F 3 AB-H2O-glycol and F 4 AB-H2O-glycol correspond to a > 2000-fold fewer prevalence of the former at reaction temperatures, which appears to leave it susceptible to hydrolysis by the residual water in o-xylene at elevated temperatures. 4 Conclusions There are two overall conclusions from this work. First is that F 3 AB is highly regioselective at all levels of conversion. This is in contrast to regioselectivities that increase with conversion or added glycol for F 4 AB and F 5 AB. Unfortunately, F 3 AB is a markedly slower catalyst. Both its slower rate and insensitivity of selectivity to conversion and added glycol appears to arise from its lower Lewis acidity and thus its relative reticence to form stable arylborane-H2O adducts. For this borane, the direct coordination between F 3 AB and the epoxide is expected to be the only catalytically-relevant intermediate. The second conclusion is that catalyst decomposition via hydrolysis by trace water is a significant problem for the use of all three arylboranes at temperatures greater than 90ºC. While they are capable of at least 1000 turnovers before deactivation, this instability may limit industrial application. However, we show here that adding a hydrogen bond acceptor such as propylene glycol stabilizes F 5 AB and F 4 AB during incubation in o-xylene. DFT predicts that these arylboranes are sufficiently Lewis acidic to form stable H2O-glycol complexes. These appear to be resistant to deactivation, and the mechanism of this protection is under investigation. Separately, glycols render these two catalysts more regioselective at all levels of conversion – an effect that has been previously discussed in detail for F 5 AB and expected to apply similarly to F 4 AB [19]. Having previously demonstrated high rates and regioselectivities in F 5 AB-catalyzed epoxide ring opening with alcohols at 60ºC and lower, this study further expands the operating conditions of arylborane catalysts. In particular, the commercially available F 5 AB catalyst has TOFs that exceed 5 s-1 under these conditions at 110ºC. Adding 10–20 equivalents propylene glycol (1–2% with respect to the limiting reactant) makes the catalyst highly regioselective at all levels of conversion and stable during incubation in o-xylene for at least an hour at this temperature. The latter is important as it might enable practitioners to push towards even higher numbers of total turnovers, as well as stabilize the catalyst against hydrolysis during storage or the initial heating of the large reactor volumes used in industry. Further work will look deeper into how arylborane structure leads to its high selectivity. CRediT authorship contribution statement Mihir Bhagat: Investigation, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Epoxide ring-opening is a key reaction in organic chemistry. We have previously shown that B(C6F5)3, a strongly Lewis acidic arylborane, exhibited high rates and unusual selectivities for catalyzing the ring-opening of aliphatic epoxides with alcohols. Here we compare catalysts of the form B(C6H5−XFX)3 (x = 5, 4, 3, and 0) and determine that moderately Lewis acidic arylboranes have higher regioselectivity, but slower rates in this reaction. At high temperatures, these arylboranes can also hydrolyze into inactive species. However, deactivation is suppressed in the presence of co-catalytic amounts of 1,2-propanediol, and DFT calculations suggest a role for arylborane-H2O-diol complexes. Thermal stabilization and regioselectivity enhancement by diol are both more pronounced for B(C6F5)3 than for less Lewis acidic B(C6HF4)3 and B(C6H2F3)3 catalysts. These results further demonstrate the catalytic relevance of H-bound networks of arylboranes and diols and enable their use at higher temperatures and greatly increased rates.
coredata.dc:title: Improving and stabilizing fluorinated aryl borane catalysts for epoxide ring-opening
